subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] One my first conversion boxes.
author: Snowfire Lioness
full_text:
----------MB_8CD5B3431EA9D7D_1094_3F5DA_webmail-d024.sysops.aol.com
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="utf-8"

 Hi Frank, do you think the electronics people knew about the voices?=C2=A0=
 Could that be the reason they made the radios to scan in silence...I wonde=
r? .sf

 



-----Original Message-----
From: Frank Sumption <purplealie=
ngirl@...>
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thu, Nov 25, 2010 2:1=
6 pm
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] One my first conversion boxes.

          =C2=
=A0                                  
=C2=A0Many, maybe most of these "digi=
tal" radios are actually analog tuners that are voltage tuned. So instead o=
f removing the tuner, as these are large boards, just add a sweep board. It=
's the same thing Hultay does. It has the advange of much better sound, sin=
ce you're using he amplifiers and speakers that it was designed with. This =
also has the built in tape deck. 
  =C2=A0
 =C2=A0The radio is kind of a cr=
ap shoot, as some are all digital, and the tuner is tuned with software, us=
ually IC-to-IC(ICsquared) a language put out by Philips. Some car tuners us=
e this, and=C2=A0I even had a couple Arm Band radio that are all digital tu=
ning. 
  =C2=A0
 =C2=A0F-S
 

=C2=A0
 On Thu, Nov 25, 2010 at 10:27 AM, Mva=
nah Maloti <inyanga4@...> wrote:
  =C2=A0          Whoa.
 =C2=
=A0
 That's wild, Frank!
 =C2=A0
 I admit to having a very limited scope an=
d knowledge of electronics in general and how these things are built and ac=
tually function specifically, but still,=C2=A0opening them up and showing u=
s "the works" like this just boggles my mind. 
  =C2=A0
 Thanks for doing w=
hat ya do, lol! 
 =C2=A0
 Converting an AM/FM/Cassette/CD player is great. =
I like it, I like it. 
 =C2=A0
 -Jerome

--- On Wed, 11/24/10, Frank Sumpti=
on <purplealiengirl@...> wrote:

 
From: Frank Sumption <pur=
plealiengirl@...>
Subject: [EVP-ITC] One my first conversion boxes=
. [1 Attachment]  
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, RTSC@yahoogroups.com

Date:=
 Wednesday, November 24, 2010, 11:35 PM  

 =C2=A0    =C2=A0AM/FM/Cassette/=
CD boom box. With an added board for linear, random and manual=C2=A0sweep, =
built 9/2008. It was sweeping out of band on FM, so I added a control to se=
t the sweep limits on the back panel, and a linear rate control on the side=
.
  =C2=A0
 =C2=A0F-S






 





 
      
                 
   
       
 =

<div style=3D"font-family: arial; color: black; font-size: 10pt;"> <b>Hi F=
rank, do you think the electronics people knew about the voices?  Coul=
d that be the reason they made the radios to scan in silence...I wonder? .s=
f</b><br>
</div>

<div> <br>
</div>

<div><br>
</div>

<div></div>

<div> Many, maybe most of the=
se "digital" radios are actually analog tuners that are voltage tuned. So i=
nstead of removing the tuner, as these are large boards, just add a sweep b=
oard. It's the same thing Hultay does. It has the advange of much better so=
und, since you're using he amplifiers and speakers that it was designed wit=
h. This also has the built in tape deck. </div>
  
<div> </div>
 
<div=
> The radio is kind of a crap shoot, as some are all digital, and the =
tuner is tuned with software, usually IC-to-IC(ICsquared) a language put ou=
t by Philips. Some car tuners use this, and I even had a couple Arm Ba=
nd radio that are all digital tuning. </div>
  
<div> </div>
 
<div>&n=
bsp;F-S</div>
 
<div><br>
<br>
 </div>

<div>Whoa.</div=

<div> </div>
 
<div>That's wild, Frank!</div>
 
<div> </div>
=
 
<div>I admit to having a very limited scope and knowledge of electronics =
in general and how these things are built and actually function specificall=
y, but still, opening them up and showing us "the works" like this jus=
t boggles my mind. </div>
  
<div> </div>
 
<div>Thanks for doing what=
 ya do, lol! </div>
 
<div> </div>
 
<div>Converting an AM/FM/Cassette=
/CD player is great. I like it, I like it. </div>
 
<div> </div>
 
<di=
v>-Jerome<br>
